I.  THE PROPOSAL 
 
1.  I submit for your approval the following report and recommendation on two proposed 
loans to the Socialist Republic of Viet Nam for the Skills Enhancement Project. The design and 
monitoring framework is in Appendix 1.  
 
2.  The project will produce a more competitive and highly skilled workforce in priority 
industries  by  developing  higher  level  training  programs  at  a  new  college  level,  while  also 
establishing  and  strengthening  system  governance  and  quality  assurance  frameworks  for 
vocational training. Studies will also strengthen the policy foundation for future development.  
 
3.  The  project  will  improve  the  quality  and  management  of  vocational  education  and 
training (VET) programs in 15 public and 5 private vocational colleges (VCs) in economic zones 
offering programs for occupations in high demand in priority industries. The programs cover 
automotive  technology,  electrical  manufacturing,  hospitality  and  tourism,  information  and 
communication technology (ICT), mechanical manufacturing, and navigation and shipping. The 
project will consist of two loans, the first to strengthen the public vocational training system and 
VCs, and the second to provide private VCs with additional resources through an onlending 
facility.  The  direct  beneficiaries  of  the  project  will  be  students  in  certificate  and  diploma 
vocational training courses, most of whom come from the rural lower middle class.  
 
II.  THE PROJECT 
 
A.  Rationale 
 
4.  Viet Nam’s poverty reduction and economic growth achievements in the last 20 years 
are a great success story. Real gross domestic product grew by an average of 8% per year from 
2003 to 2007 and per capita income increased from $441 in 2002 to $818 in 2007.1 Exports 
have been the main driver of growth, and foreign investments have been buoyant. This high 
level of growth has changed the economic structure; the share of industry and services in the 
gross domestic product has steadily increased, while the share of agriculture has declined.  
 
5.  Job growth has been strong over the decade, with changing employment patterns that 
reflect the changes in the economic structure. Agriculture's share of employment has declined 
from 66% to 50%, industry and construction has increased from 10% to 20%, while service 
sector employment has increased from 24% to 30%.  Employment growth is highest in industry 
and services, but is also strong in tourism. ICT and science and technically based industries are 
small but growing. If Viet Nam is to expand as an industrialized country, it must develop highly 
skilled industrial workers who can increase enterprise productivity, product quality and service 
standards. Viet Nam’s long-term prosperity and economic development depends on increasing 
its competitiveness in regional and global markets. For the first time, a shortage of labor has 
become an obstacle to expanding business.2 A major challenge for the VET sector, therefore, is to 
produce more and better qualified skilled workers. At present, only 13% of the employable 
workforce has vocational qualifications. 
 
6.  The VET system is being transformed by a new focus on higher level skills, through the 
recent establishment of a college level. There are currently 90 public VCs and 20 private VCs.  
In response to the demand for a more highly skilled workforce, the government has developed

2 
an excellent set of policies to strengthen the VET system, through the new Law on Vocational 
Training, 2006, effective in 2008. The major provisions of this law are (i) expansion of a more 
advanced level of training; (ii) improved VET quality and relevance; (iii) greater involvement of a 
range  of  partners,  particularly  from  the  private  sector;  and  (iv)  strengthened  VET  sector 
management  under  one  central  agency,  the  Ministry  of  Labor,  Invalids  and  Social  Affairs 
(MOLISA). Most of the groundwork for this law was laid under the Asian Development Bank 
(ADB)-supported Vocational and Technical Education Project (VTEP).3 Implementation of the 
major provisions of the law forms the foundation of the proposed project.  
 
7.  Many VET graduates lack appropriate technical and general work skills. The immediate 
causes are poor training quality and management capacity, weak sector management, and 
limited  private  sector  collaboration  and  partnerships.  This  is  underpinned  by  inadequate 
financing of the VET sector and vocational training institutions. In addition, the VET system is 
largely supply-driven, reinforced by input-focused financing and the absence of skills standards 
that link specific competencies to labor market needs. Limited collaboration with industry has 
reinforced this tendency. However, this is now changing and there is a strong desire within the 
government to build a better training system that is more relevant to industry.   
 
8.  The VTEP initiated significant reform in VET quality assurance systems, and modernized 
vocational training curricula in line with new production techniques and technologies, while 
substantially upgrading vocational secondary schools. Other donor initiatives include system 
reforms  and  strengthening  of  vocational  training  institutions  by  Agence  Française  de 
Développement, the European Union, German development cooperation through GTZ and KfW, 
the Government of the Republic of Korea, and the Government of Luxembourg. These projects 
have all been successful in strengthening the lower levels of the vocational training system and 
have expanded training opportunities for primary school and junior secondary school leavers.  
 
9.  The  VTEP  illustrated  the  value  of  experimenting  with  new  approaches  within  a 
circumscribed  context  before  system-wide  implementation.  It  focused  upon  improving  the 
technical skills of students and teachers, but weak management at the school and central levels 
undermined these efforts.4 Similarly, the absence of a training system to periodically update 
teachers' skills in response to new technologies and changing job markets hampered efforts to 
improve teacher quality. The proposed project will address both of these weaknesses.  
 
10.  Project approach. The project will address skills shortages in highly skilled occupational 
areas.  Fifteen  skilled  occupations  that  are  in  high  demand  in  high-growth  industries,  and 
relevant to government development plans for five economic zones were identified through a 
labor  market  survey  in  the  following  sectors:  (i)  automotive  technology,  (ii)  electrical 
manufacturing,  (iii)  hospitality  and  tourism,  (iv)  ICT,  (v)  mechanical  manufacturing,  and 
(vi) transport (navigation and shipping). ICT and hospitality and tourism were chosen as many 
women work in these sectors. It is expected that the number of sectors with large numbers of 
women workers will increase as new jobs are created where gender is not an obstacle.5   
 
11.  Skills shortages will be addressed through targeted occupational training programs in 
public and private VCs. Training programs linked to skills shortages will be delivered in 15 public 
VCs by providing the management and teacher development programs needed for high-skill

training,  and  high-technology  equipment.  The  five  private  VCs  will  benefit  from  the  same 
programs but new equipment will be financed through the onlending facility. All of the VCs 
selected have programs in the industry sectors selected, are located near economic zones, and 
have good facilities and training quality. The five private VCs are financially sound.6 
 
B.  Impact and Outcome 
 
12.  The impact of the project will be a reduction in skills shortages in key occupations. The 
outcome  of  the  project  will  be  the  establishment  of  higher  level  skills  training  in  15  key 
occupations. The project aims to strengthen the capacity of the VET system to train highly 
skilled  workers  and  technicians  who  can  master  the  modern  technologies  required  by 
enterprises in the industrial and service sectors. Two of the six industry sectors selected have 
high female representation to ensure that women benefit equally from the project. 
 
C.  Outputs 
 
13.  The project adopts a demand-driven approach with effective participation by the private 
sector through (i) improving the quality and management of training; (ii) upgrading at least 
20 public  and  private  VCs  so  they  can  deliver  priority  occupational  programs;  and  
(iii) strengthening partnerships with the private sector. Together these three outputs will facilitate 
the  successful  establishment  of  advanced  skills  training  by  ensuring  more  effective  sector 
management  through  uniform  standards  and  stronger  quality  assurance  to  overcome  the 
current diversity and uneven quality resulting from multiple training providers. The private sector 
will be supported to promote tighter links between the demands of the labor market and the 
vocational training system. The project will provide credit directly to private training providers to 
expand the private training colleges, and will promote closer links between industry and the 
development and delivery of training programs across the VET system.  
 
1.  Quality and Management of Training Improved 
 
14.  The project will support improvements in the quality and management of training by 
strengthening  leadership,  planning  and  management  capacities  in  MOLISA  and  the  VCs, 
improving the quality assurance system to ensure uniform quality across all VCs, developing 
skills standards and certification so trainees meet industry standards, and expanding access to 
and enrollment in VET. 
 
15.  Sector leadership enhanced. The project will promote more effective sector leadership 
and management by providing training to General Department of Vocational Training (GDVT) 
staff to build capacity in (i) policy coordination and formulation; (ii) GDVT management; and 
(iii) management  of  national  VET  quality  assurance  programs,  the  vocational  training 
information system (VTIS), and strategic planning and resource allocation. A study to formulate 
realistic cost norms for different occupational training programs will also be carried out to help 
GDVT prepare more accurate budget proposals that accurately reflect the true costs of training. 
GDVT will prepare a national VET training plan as well as annual operational plans. The project 
will improve the capacity of provincial staff from GDVT, Department of Labor, Invalids and 
Social Affairs, and other concerned ministries to manage, develop, and adapt VET training 
programs to fit the requirements of local enterprises.  
 
16.  The  project  will  also  design  a  management  information  system  to  cover  central, 
provincial, and VC levels to improve planning, monitoring, and resource allocation. This will

address one of the most serious shortcomings of the current VET system. The new information 
system will be piloted in project VCs before a national rollout. 
 
17.  Professional standards for vocational instructors will be developed to reinforce uniform 
teacher quality and allow better targeted training programs. The new professional standards will 
be aligned with the vocational qualifications framework and will incorporate both teaching and 
technical skills relevant to the selected occupational programs. A study to address the long-term 
problem of how to attract and retain vocational instructors in the VET system will be carried out.  
 
18.  Quality  assurance  strengthened.  The  project  will  implement  the  skills  standards 
currently being developed by MOLISA, and will strengthen skills testing and certification by 
supporting the development of procedures for assessment and certification, including assessor 
standards and a training program to train assessors. Assessment tools for each of the training 
programs will be developed, for use by assessors and national skills testing centers. The current 
quality accreditation program for institutions will be strengthened to ensure uniform quality of 
training, and a new system for accrediting individual training programs will be introduced.   
 
19.  On the basis of the new skills standards, curricula and training materials will be developed 
with industry involvement. A materials development team (including representatives from industry) 
will be formed for each occupational program to develop modular curriculum and training materials. 
 
20.  Access  and  enrollments  expanded.  The  project  will  support  a  national  social 
marketing campaign to enhance the poor social image of VET and thereby increase VET 
enrollments—targeting rural areas, women, and disadvantaged groups. The campaign will also 
target employers to inform them about the new programs to raise the quality of VET graduates 
and prepare them for employment. The social marketing program will train VC managers in 
strategies for marketing their training programs to local industries.  
 
  2.  Vocational Colleges Upgraded to Deliver Priority Occupational Programs 
     
21.  The project will support the upgrading of 20 VCs to strengthen the capacity of the VET 
system  to  produce  highly  skilled  technicians  and  workers  for  key  industries.  Each  of  the 
15 public VCs will be upgraded to deliver good, market-relevant training in up to three of the 15 
occupational training programs. Eight of these VCs will include training programs with the 
potential to attract larger numbers of female trainees. The management and training quality of at 
least five private VCs will also be strengthened, but their physical facilities and equipment will be 
upgraded using funds from the onlending facility. 
 
22.  Quality  of  instructors  strengthened.  The  teaching  skills  of  instructors  will  be 
strengthened through in-service training. This training will use industry employees as trainers  
and provide both students and teachers with workplace training to expose them to current work 
patterns and technologies. This will lay the foundation for a system for periodic upgrading of 
technical skills and for remodelling the VC's 6-month pre-service training program. 
 
23.  Management capacity of vocational colleges strengthened. The project will support 
the  development  of  a  modern  competency-based  management  training  program  to  train 
principals and VC management staff in strategic planning, leadership, financial management, 
monitoring of performance and cost effectiveness, and entrepreneurship and marketing.  
 
24.  Market-oriented program planning introduced. The project will train and support VCs to 
assess the quality and relevance of their training programs by measuring graduate employment

5 
and employability, primarily through regular tracer studies. To improve program planning, staff will 
be trained to conduct surveys on local skill needs and to use information from the vocational 
training and labor market information systems. The project will support a pilot program to improve 
career counseling and work placements, to improve student employment outcomes.  
   
3.  Partnerships with the Private Sector Strengthened 
 
25.  Development of private vocational colleges. Greater private sector involvement in the 
provision  of  training,  encouraged  by  incentives,  is  a  government  priority.  The  government 
supports a significant expansion of the VET system, accompanied by a gradual shifting of state 
funding  from  the  public  to  the  private  sector.  The  project  will  support  this  objective  by 
establishing a credit line for private VCs. Private VCs will be able to access credit to upgrade 
their equipment and facilities. Five private colleges have been identified by GDVT as potential 
borrowers, based on a survey of the 11 institutions that expressed interest in borrowing.7 The 
institutions were selected on the basis of their program's relevance to the project objectives as 
well as their financial soundness. The training programs proposed for funding are all in high-
technology areas: mechatronics, industrial electricity, welding, automotive technology, maritime, 
and ICT. The government is encouraging the private sector to provide more training places in 
high-technology areas such as these. The selected private VCs will be treated as part of the 
overall project, so that all human resource development, systems improvement, and other 
nonphysical inputs will be provided to the approved private VCs on a grant basis, as for the 15 
public VCs. It is expected that each institution will borrow $3 million–$4 million. More private 
VCs will be identified by GDVT if the funds are not fully absorbed. The fund will be administered 
by the Vietnam Development Bank (VDB), which will approve individual applications.8 
 
26.  Greater  involvement  of  industry.  VCs need strong managers who can forge new 
partnerships with local enterprises to facilitate work placements, more market-relevant training 
programs, and better employment opportunities for graduates. Managers will be trained on how 
to communicate and partner successfully with local companies. At the same time, the concept of 
corporate  social  responsibility  will  be  promoted  among  corporations  and  companies,  to 
encourage companies to support VET training programs and institutions consistent with their 
corporate priorities. Finally, as Viet Nam lags significantly behind its neighbors in the provision 
of direct training by companies, a study will be carried out to investigate ways in which such 
training can be stimulated.   
 
27.  Sustainability of vocational colleges improved. The project will support MOLISA's plan 
to improve the sustainability of VCs through business and service activities, including short-term 
courses for workers. Revenue from these activities can be retained by VCs and can be used to 
enhance teacher salaries and other quality improvement activities.

29.  The  government  has  requested  a  loan  in  various  currencies  equivalent  to 
SDR34,429,000 on regular terms and a loan in various currencies equivalent to SDR13,772,000 
on hard terms, both from ADB's Special Funds resources (ADF) to help finance the project. Both 
loans will have a term of 32 years, including a grace period of 8 years. The first loan, on ADF 
regular terms, is an investment loan and will have an interest rate charge of 1% per annum 
during the grace period and 1.5% per annum thereafter. The second loan, on ADF hard terms, 
is a line of credit facility (LCF) and will have an interest rate charge of 2.22% per annum for the 
life of the loan. The government will sign a subsidiary loan agreement with VDB, and will relend 
the second loan amount to VDB for LCF using the ADF hard-term rate plus a service fee. The 
relending will have a term of 20 years, including a grace period of 5 years. VDB will sign a 
project agreement with ADB specifying terms and conditions of the project component to be 
implemented by VDB, and relending and onlending of the loan amount. VDB will use the 
amount of the second loan for onlending subloans to the private VCs, under LCF, in either US 
dollars or local currency, on favorable credit terms through an onlending agreement between 
VDB and each private VC. The Onlending will have a term of maximum 20 years, including a 
grace period of 5 years. VDB will determine the interest rate and will bear the foreign exchange 
risk. The loans will be used to build workshops and purchase equipment and materials to 
improve training quality and expand access to vocational training. With respect to the free limit, 
the maximum size for each subloan permitted under the project agreement will be $7 million.

III.  DUE DILIGENCE 
 
32.  The direct beneficiaries of the proposed project will be the 24,000 students (of whom 
25% are women) currently enrolled in certificate and diploma courses. The majority come from 
rural areas and less wealthy families. From the last year of project implementation, the project 
colleges will produce 7,335 graduates annually, of whom 35% will be women.  
 
A.  Economic and Financial 
 
33.  Economic viability. The economic benefits from the project will be derived mainly from 
the incremental productivity gains resulting from improved quality and efficiency of training, 
expressed in terms of the incremental income of the graduates. While it is reasonable to expect 
that system-wide improvements in quality and efficiency will benefit all students in the VET 
system, only the incomes of graduates from programs supported by the project in public VCs 
are quantified as incremental benefits. These are the 4,000 graduates from the full-time 3-year 
courses.  Altogether,  the  project  VCs  will  benefit  24,000  students  and  will  produce  7,335 
graduates each year at a 90% completion rate from year 5. In addition, the project VCs will offer 
short courses for continuing skills upgrading. Total short course enrollment is assumed to be 1.5 
                                                 
9  Project Administration Manual (Appendix 2).

8 
times the annual intake of the diploma programs (11,500 workers per year), of whom it is 
assumed 10,328 will complete the course. An estimated 35% of the total enrollment will be 
women and members of ethnic minorities. The project's economic internal rate of return was 
estimated over a 20-year period (2010–2030) to be 15%.   
 
34.  Financial sustainability. The project requires a total government contribution of $8 million 
over its 5-year life. The government’s annual commitment to the project will reach a high of 0.8% 
of the central education budget, decreasing to 0.02% by the end of the project. The government’s 
annual commitment is therefore affordable, ranging from 0.04% to 0.15% of the VET budget. Its 
share in the project is estimated to increase from $0.65 million in year 1 to $3.9 million in year 2, 
and $2.2 million in year 3, decreasing gradually to $0.14 million by the end of the project. The 
post-project incremental personnel expenditure, estimated at about 2% of the 2010 annual budget 
of $384 million, can be absorbed. However, some of the 5% incremental increase for operations 
will be met by individual VCs. The introduction of an entrepreneurial approach will help increase 
fiscal self-sufficiency. The project is financially feasible and sustainable.  
 
B.  Governance 
 
35.  ADB  carried  out  financial  management  and  procurement  capacity  assessments  of 
MOLISA  and  GDVT.  The  financial  management  assessment  (FMA)  concluded  that  both 
agencies have the capacity to carry out the project. Their performance under the VTEP was 
satisfactory.  Nevertheless,  the  financial  assessment  did  identify  inefficient  and  outdated 
financial management and monitoring systems in MOLISA, GDVT, and VCs. The project will 
train  staff  in  financial  planning,  accounting,  auditing  and  control  and  will  implement  a 
performance-based planning and budgeting system using the cost norms to be developed under 
the project. The FMA is in the PAM.10 The procurement capacity assessment concluded that 
GDVT is experienced in procuring goods, works, and service. Although timeliness was initially 
an issue under the VTEP, this improved as the project management unit gained experience.  
 
36.  The governance assessment for the education sector in Viet Nam found that most major 
corruption risks are associated with procurement, particularly that conducted at the provincial 
level. Another source of risk comes from poor international competitive bidding specifications 
leading to bids from underqualified contractors. Efforts will be made to ensure that equipment 
specifications under the project are correct. ADB’s Anticorruption Policy (1998, as amended to 
date) was explained to and discussed with the State Bank of Vietnam and MOLISA. The PAM 
describes the specific policy requirements and supplementary measures.  
 
C.  Poverty and Social 
 
37.  Although  Viet  Nam  has  made  impressive  progress  in  reducing  poverty,  15.5%  of 
households were still impoverished in 2006. Poverty is more pronounced in rural areas (where  
poverty incidence ranges from 17% to 39%) than in urban areas and major industrial regions. A 
social  marketing  campaign  will  target  rural  students  and  young  workers,  women,  and 
disadvantaged groups to attract more students into high-level skills training.  
 
38.  The project will benefit rural lower and upper secondary school graduates, the group 
most likely to enroll in VET courses. Although the project will operate at the college level, it will 
also support overall institutional development and teacher training, which will raise the quality of 
training at the vocational secondary school level as well. Most students, particularly those from 
rural areas, will enter VCs through vocational secondary schools, whose entrance requirements 
require only completion of junior secondary school. Most students who complete regular high

9 
school  choose  university  for  further  studies.  Two  VCs  are  in  areas  with  significant  ethnic 
minority populations, most of whom are poor.  
 
39.  The Project will help address the gender inequities. Women make up nearly half of the 
labor force, but are underrepresented in skilled occupations with higher incomes. The labor force 
is  characterized  by  sex-segregation  by  occupation,  type  of  employment,  and  position.  Most 
women work in areas where they have traditionally been strongly represented, such as business 
and accounting, agriculture, and tourism and hospitality. Men dominate the industrial trades. 
Female enrollment in the VET stream reflects these patterns as vocational training institutions 
were established mainly to train for traditional male occupations in industry. However, this will 
change as many of the new jobs being created in services and industry are equally acceptable to 
men and women. VTEP institutions have had great success in increasing female enrollment and 
obtaining postgraduation salaries for women at virtually the same levels (94%) as for males.  
 
40.  The project supports effective gender mainstreaming.  To ensure that girls benefit from 
the project, a dual approach will be adopted. The training programs selected for upgrading 
under the project include two industry sectors where girls are well represented.  Simultaneously, 
pilot programs developed through school gender action plans will be supported to attract more 
girls into male-dominated sectors such as electronics and electrical installation.  
 
D.  Safeguards 
 
41.  The involuntary resettlement categorization is C, as civil works include only upgrading of 
VC  facilities  within  existing  boundaries,  and  no  new  land  acquisition  or  resettlement  is 
envisioned. The environmental categorization is also C. The indigenous peoples' categorization 
is B, as two VCs have been selected in areas with significant ethnic minority populations to 
ensure  social  equity.  The  social  marketing  strategy  for  increasing  awareness  of  VET  will 
address social and gender inequality issues. Further, the project will emphasize the importance 
of industry partners becoming more engaged in social corporate responsibility initiatives.

outputs of the project are summarized in Table 4.

43.  The major risks at the impact level are that economic growth will be slow and that highly 
skilled labor will continue to be undervalued, resulting in low salaries and few incentives to take 
up vocational training. At the outcome level, there is a risk that (i) the poor image of VET will 
inhibit enrollment growth, (ii) industry will not be willing to participate fully in developing effective 
VET programs, and (iii) expansion of the vocational teaching force will be constrained by low 
salaries and the low status of the profession. These risks are all addressed under the project. 
The major risks associated with the outputs all have reasonable mitigation measures and are 
manageable under the project. In summary, the integrated benefits and impacts are expected to 
outweigh the risks. 
 
IV.  ASSURANCES AND CONDITIONS 
 
44.  The government and MOLISA have assured ADB that implementation of the project 
shall conform to all applicable ADB policies including those concerning anticorruption measures, 
safeguards, gender, procurement, consulting services, and disbursement as described in detail 
in the PAM and loan documents. 
 
45.  In addition to the standard assurances, the government and MOLISA have agreed with 
ADB on certain covenants for the project, which are set forth in the loan agreement and project 
agreement. In addition, no withdrawals shall be made from the loan account for the LCF until 
the subsidiary loan agreement, in form and substance satisfactory to ADB, has been executed 
by the borrower and VDB, and the first onlending agreement has been executed by VDB and 
private VCs and has been submitted to ADB for review. 
 
V.  RECOMMENDATION 
46.  I am satisfied that the proposed loans would comply with the Articles of Agreement of 
the Asian Development Bank (ADB) and recommend that the Board approve 
(i)  the  loan  in  various  currencies  equivalent  to  SDR34,429,000  to  the  Socialist 
Republic of Viet Nam for the Skills Enhancement Project from ADB’s Special 
Funds resources with an interest charge at the rate of 1.0% per annum during 
the grace period and 1.5% per annum thereafter; for a term of 32 years, including 
a  grace  period  of  8  years;  and  such  other  terms  and  conditions  as  are 
substantially in accordance with those set forth in the draft loan and project 
agreements presented to the Board; and 
(ii)  the  loan  in  various  currencies  equivalent  to  SDR13,772,000  to  the  Socialist 
Republic of Viet Nam for the Skills Enhancement Project from ADB’s Special 
Funds resources with an interest charge at the rate of 2.22% per annum; for a 
term of 32 years, including a grace period of 8 years; and such other terms and 
conditions as are substantially in accordance with those set forth in the draft loan 
and project agreements presented to the Board.
